Sustainable Urban Transport

members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

I.  BACKGROUND 
 
1.  The  2006  technical  assistance  (TA)  program  of  the  Regional  and  Sustainable 
Development Department (RSDD) includes a regional TA to help developing member countries 
(DMCs) promote sustainable urban transport development.1 DMCs’ demand for knowledge in 
this area is high, and the issue is extremely relevant to the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB’s) 
current and future operations, therefore this TA responds both to DMCs’ demands and ADB’s 
operational needs. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  As cities grow exponentially, an effective and sustainable urban transport system for 
people and goods is a prerequisite for sustainable economic growth. However, urban transport 
systems in most cities are underdeveloped and their transport capacity is insufficient. Thus 
residents are unable to fully exploit economic opportunities and lack the mobility needed to 
support economic growth.  
 
3.  Urban transport systems in most cities suffer from such major constraints as insufficient 
financial resources, inefficient regulatory frameworks, poor allocation of road space, inadequate 
traffic management systems, institutional weaknesses, and underdeveloped public transport 
systems. Current urban transport systems also rarely integrate social concerns and the specific 
needs of vulnerable groups, thereby rendering such systems ineffective in relation to poverty 
reduction. Drastic increases in the number of vehicles have strained urban road networks, 
resulting in congestion for much of the day. Most of these factors disproportionately affect the 
urban poor in terms of limited access to affordable transport services, ill-health from pollution, 
and road safety concerns. 
 
4.  In most cities, road networks developed in an unplanned, ad hoc fashion, and without 
proper adherence to quality standards, are severely deficient in meeting developmental demand. 
Residential areas have few and inadequate tertiary or access roads and limited provisions for 
pedestrians, cyclists, and parked vehicles. In addition, road networks often have missing links, 
forcing the overuse of existing road sections, and the lack of circumferential roads results in 
congestion from through traffic. Meanwhile, increases in the number and uses of vehicles 
surpass the capacity of road space, adding to congestion and air pollution. As a result, transport 
conditions  in  cities  are  characterized  by  severe  congestion  and  aggravated  by  the  poor 
discipline among drivers, the incoherent enforcement of traffic laws, and an eclectic mix of 
vehicles. A failure to respond promptly to rapid motorization and the resultant congestion, along 
with  weak  enforcement  of  vehicle  emissions  standards,  results  in  degradation  of  the 
environment and stunts cities’ growth potential.2 
 
5.  Swift urbanization has also increased the number of urban poor. Efficient transport 
systems contribute to urban economic growth, thereby raising incomes and decreasing urban 
poverty. However, current urban transport systems, which do not fully integrate the specific

2  Vehicle-generated air pollution is among the serious environmental problems adversely affecting the health of city 
residents, especially the poor. The economic costs—loss of productivity and failing health—of the resultant local air

2   
needs  of  the  poor,  have  worsened  the  perverse  distributional  effects  of  urbanization.3 
Overstrained public transport systems restrict urban residents, particularly the urban poor, from 
actively participating in economic activities. The social exclusion engendered by urban transport 
makes it more difficult for the disabled to access to jobs and services. As a result, the poor find 
it hard to break out of poverty. In addition, the poor are disproportionately exposed to the risks 
associated with transport externalities, for example, they lack the means to avoid exposure to 
polluted air. Moreover, the risks they face when they travel are higher than those of the non-
poor because of the few safety provisions for pedestrians and cyclists at street crossings and 
the  slack  enforcement  of  pedestrian  crossing  facilities.  Thus  urban  transport  policies  and 
programs should take the needs of the poor into account.   
 
6.  Poor traffic management, one of the biggest issues in many cities, is a combination of 
many factors: lack of coordination and overlapping responsibilities among various agencies, 
insufficient traffic police and traffic signals, flaws in traffic markings, and ineffective enforcement 
of traffic rules and regulations. Accidents are common due to poor traffic management on one 
hand and undisciplined pedestrians and the many types of vehicles using the roads on the other. 
Poor traffic management has also resulted in encroachment by parked vehicles and commercial 
activity on roads, thereby reducing road capacity, and causing inadequate public transport 
services. Good traffic management can not only improve the flow of traffic, but can reduce 
negative environmental impacts. The need for efficient traffic management systems is therefore 
acute. Such systems will require (i) an appropriate transport policy framework under which 
governments can manage travel demand; and (ii) strategic plans that cover junction operations, 
enforcement, road use, driver re-education, public transport, parking, traffic signals, vehicle 
restrictions and circulation plans, pavement markings, vehicle condition, and equitable allocation 
of road space. 
 
7.  While a large portion of the urban population relies heavily on public transport for its 
daily activities, public transport systems in most cities are not yet adequately developed and 
investments have been limited. Bus and paratransit services, the predominant public transport 
services, are often exclusively operated by the private sector (e.g., as in Colombo, Dhaka, and 
Kathmandu).  The  unregulated  operation  of  private  buses,  particularly  with  regard  to  the 
allocation of routes and schedules, has spawned excessive competition, and as a result, the 
financial performance of public transport and the quality of service have deteriorated, negating 
the benefits derived from investments in road construction. Improving the efficiency of public 
transport should not only lower costs, but a flexible framework, which makes public transport 
more  accessible  to  the  poor.  To  this  end,  solid  institutional  and  regulatory  structures  are 
required that will help create efficient public transport systems that poor users  can afford and 
that give incentives for proper maintenance, investment, and service expansion. 
 
8.  Governments’ weak capacities lead to low institutional coordination and an inefficient 
institutional  framework.  Government  agencies  have  overlapping  or  poorly  delineated 
responsibilities,4 planning and programming are chronically fragmented and largely ad hoc, and 
institutional arrangements for policy implementation are usually incoherent. Rapidly increasing 
urban  populations  require  the  efficient  use  of  limited  land  resources  to  support  economic 
growth; however, planning for land use, urban development  and transport management is 
                                                 
3  As cities expand, the price of land that is more accessible to the city center rises. Poor people are forced to live on 
less expensive land, either in inner city slums or on distant city peripheries. Sprawling cities make the journey to 
work excessively long and costly for the poor. 
4 There is ambiguity regarding the role played by planning, programming, implementation, and operations in transport 
infrastructure and services. The structure is disjointed in that those responsible for planning and policymaking are 
often not those who implement or operate urban transport facilities and services.

3
loosely integrated, thereby constraining cities’ growth potential, competitiveness, and efficiency.  
Overall,  few  cities  are  well  organized  and  possess  competent  traffic  management  units. 
Coherent  and  integrated  plans  and  operations  under  a  wider,  more  holistic  approach  to 
transport planning, programming,  and operation are critical for an efficient urban transport 
system, and capacity to this end must therefore be developed. 
 
9.  Private sector involvement in urban transport is generally limited to the provision of 
public transport services, including buses, taxis, and trucks.5 Despite growing recognition of the 
burden that investments in major roads and subways place on municipal budgets, private sector 
participation in maintenance or construction is still rare. Public mass transit systems require 
substantial investment and careful commercial management to ensure their financial viability, for 
which private sector involvement is crucial, particularly in big cities. Planning and regulatory 
arrangements for private participation in urban transport must therefore be established. 
 
10.  The World Bank and several bilateral institutions are actively involved in urban transport 
infrastructure  and  services  in  the  region.  The  studies  and  activities  undertaken  by  these 
organizations are expected to promote a good grasp of best practices, issues, and constraints in 
relation to urban transport. Close cooperation with other donors is important to generate a well-
designed plan and coordinated programming. 
 
11.  Experience  indicates  that  piecemeal  approaches  to  sustainable  urban  transport 
development are likely to fail and that capital investments need to be supported by policy, legal, 
regulatory, and institutional reforms; capacity building; and innovative financing mechanisms 
that facilitate the provision of sustainable, high-quality transport infrastructure and services. 
More  policy  attention  must  also  be  focused  on  building  capacity  in  urban  transport 
administration, on enhancing the role and quality of affordable public transport, on financing 
mechanisms, and on the needs of pedestrians and of users of nonmotorized transport. 
 
12.  Efficiency increases once institutional reforms strengthen the capacities of governments 
to manage the framework for transport more efficiently and enhance their capacities to provide 
customer-responsive  services.  Meanwhile,  outdated  administrative  structures  are  serious 
obstacles to better operational efficiency, as these have no criteria by which to judge agency 
accountability. Agencies must free up budgetary resources to introduce sound plans, operating 
systems, and technologies. Adopting modern management systems can also increase capacity 
even without capital-intensive investment. 
 
13.  Inexpensive  access  to  income-generating  opportunities  is  an  important  means  for 
helping the urban poor up the economic ladder. Thus key social and environmental concerns 
have to be integrated into transport planning to ensure that the resultant benefits accrue to the 
poor. Inclusive transport systems require the removal of institutional and physical barriers and 
the enhancement of incentives that increase access to transport services by diverse individuals 
and groups.  
 
14.  Thus most Asian cities urgently need to establish a strategic development framework 
that  will  link  urban  transport,  effective  environmental  management,  and  inclusive  social 
development and poverty reduction. The framework will require building strong institutional 
capacities to improve traffic regulations and their enforcement; introduce integrated planning 
and  programming;  and  promote  sustainable  transport  schemes  based  on  affordable, 
                                                 
5  In Colombo, 90% of bus operations are privately run, while paratransit services (three-wheelers). Three-wheeled 
rickshaws are exclusively owned and operated by the private sector.

4   
environmentally-friendly, motorized and nonmotorized transport. To develop such a framework, 
an analysis of the policies and regulations that govern transport markets in specific jurisdictions 
will first have to be carried out, as the effectiveness of user markets is instrumental in reaping 
the benefits of transport infrastructure. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
15.  The TA aims to promote urban economic development by developing sustainable urban 
transport  systems.  The  TA  will  provide  each  of  the  selected  areas  with  (i)  a  strategic 
development  framework  for  sustainable  urban  transport;  (ii)  a  set  of  effective  investment 
programs to support efficient urban transport systems; and (iii) a set of innovative financing 
options, such as combining public and private resources and using new financing modalities. 
The TA will provide outcomes that are relevant and readily applicable to ADB’s operational 
programming. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
16.  The TA will (i) undertake a field study for each of the selected cities, taking into account 
previous studies and activities by their governments, ADB, the World Bank, the Japan Bank for 
International Cooperation, the Japan International Cooperation Agency, and other donors; and 
(ii) hold extensive consultations with national and municipal governments, local stakeholders, 
and other donors. For the field studies, the TA will include Bangladesh, People’s Republic of 
China, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.6 
 
17.  The strategic development framework will concentrate on (i) institutional capacities for 
policy, planning, and programming; (ii) adequate allocation and operation of road space; (iii) 
efficient traffic management, enforcement, and regulation; (iv) energy-efficient, environmentally-
friendly urban transport to reduce vehicle emissions; (v) urban transport safety; (vi) sectoral 
reforms pertaining to public transport, management and maintenance, and institutions; (vii) good 
governance; and (viii) inclusion of the special needs of the urban poor and of others without 
ready access to transport services in planning and programming.  
 
18.  Coherent investment programs will be designed for each of the cities that will pay 
particular  attention  to  future  investment,  which  will  add  a  regional  dimension  to  ADB’s 
investment portfolio in urban transport. Potential projects may be modern traffic management 
systems, including road user charge systems, and affordable transit systems, such as bus rapid 
transport and light rail transit. The TA will first conduct diagnostic analyses to identify the most 
urgent projects, which must be environmentally, economically, and socially sustainable. The 
final outputs of the TA will serve, individually or packaged, as a basis for interventions in urban 
transport by the regional departments. The TA will propose specific financing arrangements for 
project implementation, including combining public–private partnerships in one package and 
exploring new financing modalities. 
 
19.  The TA will build on recent, related ADB work. It will also coordinate with related ongoing 
activities in ADB, including the forthcoming urban sector strategy and the clean air initiative. The 
output of the TA will enhance ADB’s ability to engage in policy dialogue with the selected DMCs 
                                                 
6  A number of consultations with regional departments were undertaken when selecting the countries. During TA 
preparation, Dhaka (Bangladesh), Kathmandu (Nepal), and Colombo (Sri Lanka) were identified as pilot cities. For 
People’s Republic of China and Pakistan, cities will be selected during implementation.

5
and deliver lending and TA in some key areas of its operations. Furthermore, as the analytical 
work  will  include  reviews  of  successful  regional  and  global  experiences  while  suggesting 
possible future directions in the Asian context, the TA will help improve the efficiency of roads, 
vehicles, public transport operations, traffic management, and urban transport in general. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
20.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,000,000 and will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s TA funding program. The detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
21.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TA. RSDD will be responsible for overall and 
day-to-day monitoring of TA activities, including supervising and coordinating the consultants’ 
work. The TA will involve ADB-wide collaboration with the transport community of practice, 
regional departments and their transport and communications divisions, resident missions in the 
five selected countries, and the Private Sector Operations Department. The TA implementation 
team will comprise a team leader from RSDD and staff selected from within ADB. The team will 
be supported by international and national consultants. Overall supervision and guidance will be 
provided by a task force chaired by the team leader and composed of representatives from the 
departments  concerned.  The  fielding  of  consultants  is  scheduled  for  November  2007  and 
consulting  services  will  be  carried  out  over  18  months  for  completion  in  April  2008.  The 
consultants will procure equipment in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines. 
 
22.  The TA will require a total of 93 person-months of consulting services, including 23 
person-months for individual international consultants, 10 person-months for individual national 
consultants,  and  60  person-months  for  national  institute  consultants.  Appendix  3  presents 
outline terms of reference.7 The international consultants will provide expertise in (i) urban 
transport, with specialties in transport policy, planning, traffic management, and public transport; 
(ii) urban development, with a specialty in capacity building; (iii) poverty and social development; 
and (iv) financial management and private sector participation. The consultants will be engaged 
by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. 
 
23.  The TA implementation team will collaborate closely and consult regularly with ADB 
regional departments and relevant networks. As appropriate, the team will organize discussions, 
workshops, and seminars to assess findings from the viewpoint of operational needs. The 
outputs of the TA will be compiled as a knowledge product and will ultimately be integrated into 
country partnership strategies. The findings of the TA will be widely disseminated through 
various modalities, including publication, country workshops, and seminars. The TA’s outcome 
should be evaluated bearing in mind ADB’s policy dialogue with DMCs, demand for ADB 
assistance, and developments in DMCs related to sustainable urban transport systems. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for Sustainable Urban Transport, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
                                                 
7  The 60 person-months of national institute consultancy will be undertaken by five national teams from the selected 
countries. The detailed arrangements for the country teams will be finalized with the assistance of the team leader 
during TA inception.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require a total of 93 person-months of consulting 
services, including 23 person-months for individual international consultants, 10 person-months 
for individual national consultants, and 60 person-months for national institute/firm consultants. 
Under  the  guidance  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  team,  the  consultants  will  (i) 
undertake field studies in Bangladesh, People’s Republic of China, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri 
Lanka, taking into consideration previous studies and activities by the  governments, ADB, the 
Japan Bank for International Cooperation, the Japan International Cooperation Agency, the 
World Bank, and other donors; and (ii) hold extensive consultations with national and municipal 
governments, local stakeholders, and other donors. The consultants will (i) build on all recent 
and related ADB work and coordinate with related ongoing activities in ADB, (ii) identify best 
practices directly applicable to future ADB operations in urban transport, and (iii) make practical 
recommendations to the governments.  
 
2.  The consultants will include five country teams of national consultants that will be formed 
during project inception. The international consultants will oversee and coordinate closely with 
each of the country teams. Country workshops will be held in each city to discuss the initial 
design of the study and the final proposed output. The consultants will maintain close contact 
with  government  officials  and  with  other  donors.  The  team  leader  will  be  responsible  for 
coordinating the work of the country teams assisted by the national study coordinator and 
ensure that the outputs from each country team are in line with overall requirements.  
 
B.  Consultants  
 
1.  Urban Transport Specialists (international, 12.0 person-months) 
 
3.  The team leader will be an urban transport specialist. The team leader will work closely 
with ADB, supervise and coordinate staff, and liaise with relevant government counterpart staff 
and national consultant teams to ensure timely implementation of the TA. The team leader will 
have primary technical responsibility for reviewing and building on previous studies on urban 
transport  in  the  selected  cities  and  coordinating  with  the  central  government,  municipal 
governments, local stakeholders, other donors, and team members to prepare a report that 
addresses the requirements for implementable and sustainable urban transport policies, plans, 
and programs that ADB can use as a guide for future operations. The team leader will provide 
technical guidance and direction to international consultants and national country teams in each 
of the selected cities to ensure that a focused approach is applied to the work.  
 
4.  The consultants will undertake analytical work to prepare operationally relevant, Asian 
focused, implementable frameworks for future interventions that cover all areas of sustainable 
urban  transport,  including  traffic  management  and  enforcement,  road  networks  and  their 
maintenance, public transport provision and operations, institutional arrangements, policy, and 
programming. This will involve reviewing existing literature and urban transport or land use 
studies, including ongoing work within and outside ADB, collecting relevant data, and analyzing 
trends and issues. 
 
5.  The consultants will prepare a detailed framework analysis of urban transport; its current 
situation as well as the legal, regulatory, and institutional arrangements. The impact of urban 
transport  externalities  on  pollution,  safety,  and  access  by  all  members  of  society  will  be

Appendix 3  10 
examined. Examination of previous urban transport studies and of the ability to implement 
identified priority projects will be used to assess and highlight any shortcomings in current 
delivery  and  operations.  Remedial  actions  required  to  ensure  successful  and  efficient 
implementation of future schemes and operational changes will be recommended.  
 
6.  For urban transport, traffic management, public transport, road maintenance, road space 
allocation, enforcement, safety, pollution, and affordability, the consultants will evaluate the 
current situation and future directions and what impacts institutional arrangements have on 
urban transport and on an enabling framework. Special attention will be given to how policy is 
developed and acted upon and how urban transport infrastructure and services are planned and 
programmed, implemented, and financed. The study will emphasize the social, environmental, 
and  economic  impacts  of  urban  transport.  An  evaluation  framework  for  sustainable  urban 
transport  will  be  developed,  drawing  on  the  findings  of  the  review  and  incorporating 
enhancements  required  to  ensure  more  effective  and  efficient  transport  infrastructure  and 
service delivery and operations in the future. 
 
7.  The detailed study tasks will be further refined at the inception stage, but will include 
developing outline regulatory and policy frameworks, planning and programming, and robust 
financial and operational plans. Together with the team of consultants, the urban transport 
specialist will support and conduct seminars and workshops, help locate appropriate resource 
persons and institutions, review all deliverables and workshop materials, and coordinate the 
various activities required for the successful completion of the project.  
 
8.  The consultants will propose effective investment programs to promote efficient urban 
transport systems and will assess and propose adequate road network and public transport 
systems to meet developmental demand. Coherent and progressive investment programs will 
be designed for each of the cities. Particular attention will be given to future investment, which 
will add a regional dimension to ADB’s investment portfolio in urban transport, ones that can 
provide key examples of best practices and replicable structures for future projects.  
 
9.  The  consultants  will  propose  efficient  traffic  management  systems  to  significantly 
improve the cities’ internal traffic conditions at minimal cost. The systems will require (i) an 
appropriate transport policy framework under which governments can manage the demand for 
transport by private vehicles; and (ii) strategic plans that cover junction operations, enforcement, 
road  use,  intelligent  transport  systems,  education,  public  transport,  parking,  traffic  signals, 
vehicle restrictions, pavement markings, vehicle condition, and equitable allocation of road 
space for all users. Current traffic management and highway maintenance in the cities will be 
reviewed, including the enforcement of traffic management laws and regulations. Proposals will 
be  produced  to  ensure  effective  and  efficient  traffic  management  with  safe  and  equitable 
allocation  of  road  space.  Schemes  will  be  proposed  that  improve  the  efficiency  of  public 
transport, which will not only lower costs, but a flexible framework, which makes public transport 
more accessible to the poor. Solid institutional and regulatory structures will be proposed, which 
will help create affordable public transport systems for poor users and give incentives for proper 
maintenance, investment, and service expansion. 
 
10.  The consultants will establish a strategic development framework that will link urban 
transport,  effective  environmental  management  and  inclusive  social  development.  The 
framework will require building new institutional capacities to improve regulatory frameworks; 
introduce better land use planning; and promote integrated transport infrastructure schemes 
based on affordable, environmentally-friendly public transport and nonmotorized transport.

Appendix 3  11 
11.  The consultants will propose institutional reforms, which will increase efficiency and 
strengthen the capacities of governments to manage the transport frameworks for effective 
delivery and operation and enhance their capacities to provide customer-responsive services by 
means of financially sustainable operations. The requirements for agencies to allocate scarce 
budgetary  resources  to  develop  and  introduce  sound  plans  and  operating  systems  and 
incorporate  the  latest  technologies  will  be  given  a  high  priority.  Modern  integrated  public 
transport networks, which can increase overall network capacity through low capital-intensive 
investment, will be promoted. 
 
12.  Current public transport operations in the cities will be reviewed, along with future plans 
and  the  effectiveness  of  service  provision.  Coverage  by  public  transport,  route  allocation, 
affordability, and service will be reviewed to assess the ability of public transport to meet current 
and future demand. The integration of public transport services will be reviewed and measures 
will be recommended  to ensure integrated and adequate service provision. The level of private 
sector involvement in public transport will be given special attention, as will the requirements to 
ensure financially viable public transport operations.   
 
13.  The  consultants  will  develop  a  strategic  framework  that  will  link  sustainable  urban 
transport, effective environmental management, and inclusive social development. The strategic 
framework will concentrate on (i) institutional capacities for integrated policy, planning, and 
programming; (ii) adequate allocation and operation of road space for all transport modes and 
users; (iii) efficient traffic management and enforcement systems, including a robust and reliable 
regulatory framework; (iv) energy-efficient urban transport; (v) urban transport and road safety; 
(vi)  reforms  of  urban  transport  services,  traffic  management,  and  maintenance;  (vii)  good 
governance; and (viii) inclusion of the special needs of the urban poor and of others without 
ready access to transport services in planning and programming.  
 
2.  Urban Development Specialist (international, 3.0 person-months) 
 
14.  The urban development specialist will undertake theoretically sound analytical work to 
prepare  an  operationally  relevant  and  Asia-focused  knowledge  product  covering  the  latest 
modalities  and  innovative  solutions  for  urban  development  and  institutional  capacity 
development. This will incorporate a review of existing literature and studies of the selected 
cities, including work ongoing within and outside ADB, collection of data, analysis of trends and 
issues, identification of good practices and innovative approaches, and suggestions for the 
future. Innovative approaches to incorporating urban development and transport will be required, 
and proposed options will feed into the development framework, and must therefore be realistic 
and  implementable,  while  being  financially,  environmentally,  socially,  and  economically 
sustainable.  
 
15.  The consultant will (i) review the responsibilities and activities of relevant government 
agencies, including their work practices and interactions between agencies; and (ii) provide 
background and insights on the institutional framework as it relates to urban development and 
urban transport systems and operations. The consultants will delineate the responsibilities of 
each institution and prepare proposals for improved coordination among agencies to boost 
government efficiency in the urban and transport sectors. This will require assessing capacities 
and  developing  consistent  and  integrated  land  use  and  transport  plans,  plus  methods  for 
delivery and operations under a holistic approach to urban transport and urban development 
that covers the entire programming process for land use planning and transport infrastructure 
and operations. The consultants will examine governance issues and assess the impacts poor 
governance has on the urban transport.

Appendix 3  12 
 
3.  Social Development Specialist (international, 4.0 person-months) 
 
16.  In close collaboration with the transport specialist, the consultant will  
 
(i)  Assess economic participation by the urban poor and the impacts of accessibility 
and transport costs.  
(ii)  Design specific transport programs targeting the urban poor, such as subsidized 
travel.  
(iii)  Provide insights in relation to the inclusiveness of society as stakeholders in 
policy and urban transport planning and service delivery, recommend how urban 
transport systems can reflect the needs of the poor.  
(iv)  Design inexpensive access to income-generating opportunities.  
(v)  Assess the impacts of pollution on disadvantaged groups and propose measures 
to mitigate the impacts.   
(vi)  Identify key social and environmental concerns to be integrated into transport 
planning to ensure that development benefits accrue to the poor.  
(vii)  Integrate social issues into the planning and management of urban transport.  
(viii)  Prepare standards for pedestrians and bicyclists in traffic law.  
(ix)  Identify institutional and physical barriers to access by diverse individuals and 
groups to transport services and enhance incentives to improve access.  
(x)  Assess the impact of major transport infrastructure projects on the urban poor, 
particularly relocation requirements.  
(xi)  Prepare a framework for integrating nonmotorized transport into the planning 
procedures of municipal authorities.  
 
4.  Financial Management Specialist (international, 4.0 person-months) 
 
17.  The  consultant  will  outline  planning  and  regulatory  arrangements  for  private  sector 
participation in urban transport and innovative financing options, such as combining public and 
private resources and using new financing modalities. The consultant will (i) review private 
sector participation and policy reform issues, planning, resource needs, and impact on the 
operation and maintenance of roads and other transport services and the status of private 
sector participation in the transport sector in the cities; and (ii) recommend, if necessary, a 
corporate  structure  and  appropriate  schedule  for  achieving  sound  and  sustainable 
commercialization of the transport operating entity. Based on lessons from previous projects, 
due attention will be given to enhance transparency in the bidding process for the private sector 
to  optimize  the  gains  of  a  concession  or  franchise.  A  model  public-private  partnership 
framework will be developed, if relevant, that will specify the concession period and selection 
criteria and ensure adequate pricing and transparent bidding. 
 
  5.  Study Coordinator (national, 10.0 person-months) 
 
18.  A  study  coordinator  will  be  hired  in  the  Philippines  and  will  be  responsible  for 
coordinating the work and outputs of the various team members, including the national country 
teams;  providing  support,  and  liaising  closely  with  the  team  leader.  The  coordinator  will 
undertake the following specific tasks:

Appendix 3  13 
(i)  Coordinate the work of and provide support to the project team and the TA 
implementation team, including interaction between the international consultants 
and the five national country teams to ensure consistency in relation to individual 
issues and the overall framework.  
(ii)  Plan the format of the output, including the contents of the overall transport 
system and investment framework and the summary paper.  
(iii)  Interact closely with all the specialists throughout their assignments.  
(iv)  Finalize conclusions with the specialists and integrate their outputs with that of 
the team leader.  
(v)  Help the team leader prepare an initial draft of the proposed output. 
(vi)  Ensure that initial draft reports are circulated and made available to relevant 
government agencies, other donors, and all stakeholders. 
(vii)  Finalize the draft reports incorporating comments received from ADB staff. 
 
6.  National Institute or Firm Consultants (60.0 person-months) 
 
19.  In each of the five countries selected for the field studies, a national institute or firm will 
be recruited that will have specialists in urban transport planning and programming, urban and 
transport  institutional  development,  transport  policy  and  regulation,  urban  transport 
management and enforcement, and poverty and social development. Each country team will 
work closely with the international team and provide relevant information about and insights into 
the  various  aspects  of  sustainable  urban  transport  in  relation  to  current  conditions  and 
operations, proposed development plans, and any institutional and operational adjustments 
currently under consideration. 
 
20.  The total 60 person-months of national institute/firm consultants will be roughly evenly 
distributed among the five countries, with around 6 person-months for each country allocated for 
urban  transport-related  requirements  and  about  2  person-months  for  poverty  and  social 
development. As the required inputs from each area of expertise may vary among countries, 
specific  durations  and  terms  of  reference  for  consulting  services  for  each  country  will  be 
finalized during the inception stage.  
 
21.  The main tasks of the national country teams will be to provide (i) high-quality, research-
based, and local knowledge inputs to the international consultants; and (ii) information required 
for an in-depth understanding of the current urban transport situation. A list of key issues and 
constraints within each of the cities will be prepared and compared with international experience 
to develop action plans and proposals for sustainable urban transport policies and for plans and 
programs  with  robust  finances  and  institutional  arrangements  for  both  implementation  and 
operation. The national consultants will make sure that appropriate government agency staff are 
included in discussions during the TA and that all relevant central, local, and nongovernment 
organizations are informed of the findings of the study in order to provide additional insights.  
 
22.  The TA is expected to commence in November 2006 and be completed by April 2008. 
The consultants will submit the reports to ADB following this schedule: (i) inception report, 
7 weeks  after  the  commencement  of  services;  (ii)  interim  report,  17  weeks  after 
commencement; (iii) draft final report, 27 weeks after commencement of services; and (iii) final 
report, 7 weeks after receiving all comments.
